work.name: Max Planck Institute for Intelligent Systems Tübingen, Germany
work.summary: Research focus: Collective action in machine learning and development of generative model frameworks. Studied how a change of optimization and learning algorithm affects the success of collective action. Investigated the connection between density estimation to a simpler training algorithm for WGANs. Supervised by Samira Samadi (MPI-IS) and Amartya Sanyal (University of Copenhagen). Previous work in the Perceiving Systems department, developing a 3D articulated model of laboratory rats with Michael J. Black (MPI-IS), Silvia Zuffi (IMATI-CNR) and Sergi Pujades (INRIA) using computer vision tools.

work.name: Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel
work.summary: Applied signal processing and matched filtering on gravitational waves data to detect binary black holes. Worked with Barak Zackay.

work.name: The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Israel
work.summary: Developed an algorithm to estimate kinematic parameters of flies from video using a 3D model. Supervised by Tsevi Beatus.

work.name: Intel, Petah Tikva, Israel
work.summary: Developed and maintained scripts for automated testing and quality assurance.

work.name: IDF technological unit
work.summary: Developed mechanical devices, including ideation, 3D CAD design, technical drawings, assembly, testing and documentation.

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).
